subject: Real Estate
title: Bailouts: Too Big to Fail
description: A fast breakdown of Bailouts: Too Big to Fail for builders.

hook.text: In 2008, the U.S. government bailed out banks with $700 billion in taxpayer money. It wasn't a choice.

buildup.text: If major banks collapsed, ATMs would stop, payrolls would fail, and the economy would shut down.

discovery.text: 'Too big to fail' means a bank is so interconnected that its collapse threatens the entire system.

twist.text: The bailout saved the system â€” but it also told banks they could take risks without consequences.

climax.text: After 2008, the biggest banks got even bigger. The too-big-to-fail problem is larger than before.

punchline.text: Saving the system taught banks they'd always be saved.

quiz.question: What does 'too big to fail' mean?
options: A bank's collapse would threaten the entire system
